title: S5E90 | Magnolia Dove - From Satanic Ritual Abuse & MK ULTRA Networks to Angelic Intervention
transcript:
Title: S5E90 | Magnolia Dove - From Satanic Ritual Abuse & MK ULTRA Networks to Angelic Intervention
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yife06w3W5Q
Video ID: yife06w3W5Q
--------------------------------------------------
Kind: captions Language: en Heavenly Father, today we put on the full armor  to protect us against attack. We put on the belt   of truth to protect against lies and deception. We  put on the breastplate of righteousness to protect   our hearts from the temptations. We put the gospel  of peace on our feet to walk in your light, peace,   and freedom with the Holy Spirit. We rebuke  anxious thoughts. We take up your shield of   faith for protection to block and destroy all  the darts and threats thrown at us by the enemy.   We put on the helmet of salvation to cover  our minds and thoughts, reminding us that we   are children of a mighty king. We are forgiven,  set free, saved by the blood of Jesus. We take   up the sword of the spirit, your living word  that has the power to demolish strongholds   and is sharper than any double-edged sword. We  come to you, Lord, in prayer daily. In Jesus   mighty name we pray. Amen. Amen. What's up, you  guys? Welcome to the Imagination. I'm your host,   Emma, and today I'm absolutely honored to  introduce you all to satanic ritual abuse,   MK Ultra Mind Control, covert experimentation,  an organized abuse survivor, whistleblower,   and overcomer, artist and painter, writer,  songwriter, spiritual conduit, and healer,   and a woman who transforms the unspeakable into  a testament of the soul's unyielding sovereignty.   Magnolia Dove, born into a lineage marked by  survival and struggle. Magnolia's story began with   roots in her mother's Holocaust survivor heritage  and a rare AB positive bloodline, which made her a   target immediately from birth. While the specifics  of generational abuse remain partly shrouded,   the echoes of trauma reverberated through her  family. Her childhood spent in the loving yet   dysfunctional embrace of her parents, an only  child navigating her father's cocaine addiction,   was marred by early dissociation, a survival  mechanism that veiled her earliest memories.   At age 5, the darkness descended fully, Magnolia  became a target of ritual abuse and mind control.   Ins snared by perpetrators tied to MK Ultra and  Stargate projects, the sisters of Darkness Coven,   and even her best friend's parents who were linked  to the Warner Brothers and Hollywood circles. Her   formative years were a battleground at private  school and later in public schools. Magnolia   was subjected to routine programming even as she  excelled in her school's gate programs. The abuse   was harrowing. satanic rituals where she was hung  upside down, adrenalized blood being extracted,   a shallow coffin burial with snakes and bugs,  electroshock wands, starvation and padded rooms,   bamboo shoots under her fingernails, and more  as part of her brutal traumabased mind control   programming. At Warner Brothers linked gatherings,  she even endured child adult fetish parties,   a grim echo of the movie Eyed Wise Shut.  These horrors, layered with drug-induced   programming and near-death experiences, sought to  fracture her spirit. The abuse began to wne around   age nine when key perpetrators, including  her primary babysitter and sexual abuser,   moved away. MK Ultra's grip loosened, though  sporadic access for programming persisted.   Magnolia buried these memories deep, blocking  them out into adulthood, a survival strategy   that allowed her to move forward until the past  demanded reckoning. Just over a decade ago,   a chilling memory of a perpetrator's Russian  roulette threat unlocked a flood of memories   linked to satanic ritual abuse. Over the next few  years, the pieces coalesed, revealing the truth of   her life that had been mentally compartmentalized.  Magnolia's healing journey has been as fierce as   her survival. Initially, her treatments offered  little emotional support and trauma rehab provided   only surface level understanding of her complex  trauma and PTSD. Her true healing came through   unconventional and holistic paths and a profound  connection to Jesus Christ through deliverance.   Today, Magnolia stands as a whole, vibrant soul  with many memories integrated, yet ever curious   about the gaps in her story. Her decision to speak  out is driven by a desire to provide hope, to fill   in other survivors fragmented memories, and to  reclaim her testimony. As a songwriter, painter,   writer, and healer, she is a master at turning  the painful into the beautiful into creations that   resonate with ancient wisdom and urgent relevance.  her work as a lifeline for those navigating the   liinal space between trauma and transcendence.  As a radiant vessel of Yeshua's divine light,   Magnolia channels transformative healing messages  and profound spiritual wisdom, guiding those   yearning for restoration and truth through their  deepest wounds. With unwavering devotion, she   creates a sacred sanctuary for survivors of ritual  abuse, SRRA, and mind control, offering services   like deliverance, boundless compassion, and a path  to wholeness and reintegration. Title: TIP Movie Night | CKLN MC Radio Series P2 - Dr. Colin Ross Mind Control Interview with Wayne Morris
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j7vhgKG_W2w
Video ID: j7vhgKG_W2w
--------------------------------------------------
Kind: captions Language: en KN and we're continuing on with a series of  mind control in Canada. We've heard over the   last 3 weeks a lecture by Dr. Colin Ross about  the history of the CIA and military mind control   experimentation programs uh documented history.  Today we're going to start a an interview part   one of a two-part interview with Dr. Colin  Ross as we go into a bit more detail and   uh explore the other many issues around this  situation. You're listening to CKLN 88.1. I'm speaking with Dr. Colin Ross, a psychiatrist  and researcher practicing in Dallas, Texas. And   uh uh Dr. Ross, I wonder if you could just  uh briefly describe who you are and what your   current work is. Sure. I'm a Canadian by birth and  training. I went to medical school in Edmonton and   did my psychiatry training in Winnipeg. I moved  down here to Dallas just a little over 5 years   ago. I'm a specialist in multiple personality  disorder and I've written a number of different   books and lots of research papers and so on on  that. Right now I'm working at a hospital in the   Dallas area here. We have a program that we run  on contract for the hospital which treats mostly   people with multiple personality disorder. also  uh other related disorders. Most of the people   that we treat describe very traumatic and abusive  childhoods. Now um what is a dissociative identity   disorder and is it the same thing as multiple  personality disorder? Dissociative identity   disorder is the official new name for multiple  personality disorder hasn't really caught on   in the general language. It's a professional  technical term. In 1994, that new diagnosis was   introduced. It just replaces multiple personality  disorder and the criteria for diagnosing it   have been changed a little bit basically by  adding a requirement for some type of amnesia,   but basically it means the same thing as multiple  personality. So, what does it mean when somebody   has this disorder? What Well, the basic criteria  for diagnosing are pretty straightforward.   You have these different personality states or  identities that take turns being in control of the   body and there's some sort of amnesia or memory  barrier between the different personality states.   The several important points to understand about  this disorder are first of all it's not literally   true that they have different personalities.  They just have these fragmented components of   one personality and those have been referred to  as different personalities for over 100 years but   they're not literally different personalities.  There isn't really more than one person there.   And there's several different ways you can end  up having multiple personality. One way, which is   what we think we see most of the time clinically,  is where you've basically been physically,   sexually, emotionally abused or neglected as a  child, and you create these different identities   to cope with it and hold different memories and  feelings about it and so on. And that can be,   as I said, a combination of various types  of trauma in childhood. It has to be fairly   serious trauma usually. Then another way that  you can get multiple personality is um where   it's created either by mistake or deliberately by  somebody else. And that could be in a bad therapy   which is all out of control and not being handled  properly. And then the other major way of arriving   at multiple personality disorder is people  who have what's called a factitious disorder.   That means that they deliberately fake having  it either to get into the patient role or get   attention or get out of something or for some  specific purpose. Now, have you seen this disorder   occur um due to trauma as an adult or does it  specifically happen while while a child? Well,   there's some cases reported in the literature and  there's the odd case where it's trauma that starts   in adulthood, but vast majority of time it seems  to be childhood. Right. We've uh listened to your   lecture um talking about the history of uh US mind  control. You refer to the term yatrogenic. What   does that mean? Yatrogenic is just a Greek word  that means created by the doctor. So yatrogenic   multiple personality is multiple personality  that's created by mistake by a bad therapist   who's using improper techniques. Okay. How did you  get involved in working with people suffering from   DID? Well, I actually diagnosed my first case  when I was a medical student in Edmonton and   uh just instantly found it really fascinating  and interesting. And then when I was doing my   four years of psychiatry training in Winnipeg,  I saw one more case and I thought it was going   to be too rare to really specialize in. But then  in ' 85 when I finished my psychiatry training,   I diagnosed another case and then I got some  referrals and then more referrals and then I   got a reputation for it and ended up getting lots  of referrals from all kinds of different people in   Western Canada and gradually sort of switched over  to that being my specialty. And this this was when   you were operating a practice in is it Winnipeg or  Edmonton at the time? Yeah, Winnipeg. Right. I was   a full-time uh university professor of psychiatry  at one of the hospitals there. And and what did   you find from what were your findings from working  with people with DID or MPD? Well, I've published   just on multiple personality and related things.  I've published probably about 60 or so papers in   the professional literature. So, I've found quite  a few different things, but the main theme is   really goes through the whole multiple personality  literature. And that is that people who have this   diagnosis clinically uh have lots of other things  going on at the same time. lots of depression,   lots of anxiety, drug and alcohol problems,  eating disorder problems, sleep problems. So,   they don't just have multiple personality,  they got all kinds of different symptoms. They   also tend to be in the health care system for  quite a long period of time. Not all the time,   but the majority of cases are in the health care  system getting psychiatric treatment for one thing   or another for quite a while. On average about  uh 7 years before the multiple personality is   diagnosed. And the other theme that we see going  all the time is this childhood trauma that arises   as a way of coping with childhood trauma. And then  we just uh actually just found out this week that   a paper has been accepted at the American  Journal of Psychiatry where we assessed 103   people with this diagnosis here in Dallas about  uh almost exactly four years ago now. We gave   them a whole bunch of different questionnaires  and standardized tests and interviews and so on.   And then we followed up as many as we could two  years later. And we were able to follow up 54 of   them. And the uh reduction in all these different  symptoms was really impressive. And 12 already in   the first two years of follow-up, 12 of the 54  people were all integrated back into one person.   So they had a really dramatic and meaningful  reduction in not just the amount of multiple   personality related symptoms, but depression,  anxiety, substance abuse, all kinds of things.   So this is the first uh scientifically designed  kind of treatment outcome study that really   shows that good treatment can be very helpful. So  these people that you're talking about did undergo   treatment with you or other other therapists came  they came to our hospital usually for an average   of about 17 days or so. Mhm. Uh 70% of our people  are from outside Texas. So they're from all over   the United States and we've had probably about  15 admissions of people from Ontario and they   were then go home and are followed up by their  therapists. So they only get about usually two,   three, sometimes four weeks with us and they may  go into our day hospital program for a little bit   as well, but basically they're followed up by  therapists all over the country. And are these   therapists in contact with you in terms of um  methods of therapy? Yeah, they've usually read   my books and been to some of my workshops and  are aware of my approach, but they don't have   to necessarily follow my approach. Right. And  these other symptoms that you were talking about,   do you feel that they were also a result of  childhood trauma? Yeah, the whole package seems   to be related to childhood trauma. Uh now we got a  lot of controversy about this going on in society   in the psych psychology, psychiatry, sociology  and so on, right? And we need a lot more research,   but that's the best understanding I have right  now. And there's fair bit of research data that   backs that up. It's not totally nailed down  scientifically. Mhm. Um, I'm wondering from   your experience working in in Canada, how has the  Canadian medical system responded to your your   findings in in MPD research? Well, roughly about  the same as American. Overall, there's a lot of   skepticism, a lot of political agitation, fair bit  of negative hostile propaganda and backstabbing   about it. And u, and then there's also quite a  lot of support. And obviously if I've gotten 50   or 60 professional papers published, I'm getting a  reasonable reception. The main difference between   Canada and the United States was in Canada, I just  couldn't get the financial or clinical support to   set up and run a program. And the reason that's  possible down here is because there's a private   for-profit sector in the mental health system  that's profit driven. That's a business. and   the the hospital corporation I contract with  is traded on the New York Stock Exchange and so   on. And since I attract patients, then there's a  financial motive for the hospital to be interested   in me providing that service. So that financial  motive allows the system to sort of set aside all   of these ideological and political debates that  go on and so therefore I'm able to run a program.   So for the uh survivors of childhood abuse that  you're dealing with, I I guess they would have to   have access to some kind of um funds to be able  to undergo therapy. What what what is your sense   of of uh people um that have undergone this in  childhood that do not have access to to therapy?   Well, the uh breakdown in terms of insurance  coverage that we have in our program is roughly   about 50% are on Medicare, which is a government  disability program. So, they're sort of like   Canadian healthcare system people in that their  health insurance is basically paid for by the   government. And they also get disability welfare  type payments for their basic support and living.   So, half of our people are really insured in a way  fairly similar to Canada. Then the other half have   some sort of private insurance through their  employers or their spouse's employers. The if   you're in the one-third of people in the United  States who don't have proper medical insurance,   then you can't get proper medical care, including  psychiatric and including the kind we provide. So   that would seem to be uh probably a reason to  think that the Canadian health care system is   superior to the US. The funny thing is that if you  have multiple personality or a related disorder,   your odds of getting treatment are actually  better in the United States because there's   more programs and more therapists available. In  Canada, even though you have universal access   and universal coverage and actual practical  reality, you can't get the treatment. So, you   got theoretical universal coverage for multiple  personality and trauma related disorders, but you   don't have real practical coverage in reality.  Well, the sort of paradox is that in the United   States actually a higher percentage of people who  could benefit from psychotherapy for all kinds of   problems arising from their childhoods um who  can actually get therapy is higher in the US.   Interesting. Um now in your previous lecture you  did uh go into a lot of um uh detail outlining the   history of mind control. What is the link between  MPD and mind control experimentation? Well,   how I got into this is a sort of a backdoor  route. I I didn't really have any interest in   the CIA or the military or mind control research  or all of that. Particularly when I left Canada,   hadn't read about it. Hadn't really heard  any other doctors talking about it. Hadn't   heard any patients talking about it. And pretty  soon after I arrived in Texas in early 1992,   multiple personality patients started talking  about kind of real strange experiences I didn't   know what to make of that involved either going  into hospitals, some sort of research setting   somewhere on a military base and having different  kinds of experiments done on them which involved   um EEG machines or some kind of scientific  equipment and sensory deprivation,   maybe physical spinning, maybe hallucinogens,  and it wasn't any kind of uh cult and obviously   wasn't just their parents or something going  on in their family. And initially I thought   that was really too much to believe. But then I  decided I should at least look into it a little   bit. So I started basically in early '92 doing a  little bit of reading. And the more reading I did,   what amazed me was that instead of coming to the  conclusion, oh well, this is not possible. There's   no documentation of this kind of stuff. Actually,  the more I read, the more documentation I got that   all kinds of absolutely unbelievable and bizarre  and unethical and harmful mind control research   has been done in Canada and the United States  since the Second World War. And I've actually   um interviewed and spoken with a number of people  who have documented mind control research. title: S5E88 | Kevin Annett - Governing Ourselves: A Guide for Personal, Political, & Spiritual Sovereignty
transcript:
Title: S5E88 | Kevin Annett - Governing Ourselves: A Guide for Personal, Political, & Spiritual Sovereignty
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLZZwNSLQ0I
Video ID: gLZZwNSLQ0I
--------------------------------------------------
Kind: captions Language: en What's up you guys? Welcome to the imagination.  I'm your host, Emma, and today I'm honored to have   back on the show once again, podcast regular,  United Church minister, turned whistleblower,   Canadian hero, humanitarian, loving father,  published writer and author, public speaker   and podcaster, documentary filmmaker, Nobel Peace  Prize nominee, co-founder of the international   tribunal into crimes of church and state,  righteous soul, and eagle strong voice,   Kevin Annet. In case you've missed any of Kevin's  past episodes or our movie night feature where we   aired his acclaimed documentary, Unrepentant  on this channel, here's a brief intro into his   testimony and background along with some helpful  information on what we'll be talking about today.   Kevin's early life was shaped by compassion and  a call to serve as a United Church minister in   Port Alurnie, British Columbia in the early  1990s. their indigenous survivors of Canada's   residential schools revealed a hidden genocide,  abuse, forced sterilizations, and child deaths   orchestrated by church and state. Kevin's refusal  to stay silent led to his 1997 defrocking, a   historic first for political reasons. Undeterred,  he documented survivors stories and produced the   2006 documentary Unrepentant, which exposed these  atrocities and helped prompt Canada's 2008 apology   to indigenous survivors. His investigations  reached global elites, including the Vatican,   leading him to co-found the International Tribunal  into Crimes of Church and State in 2010. His work   with the International Common Law Court of Justice  contributed to Pope Benedict's 2013 resignation,   a historic event linked to allegations of  church crime. Despite facing smear campaigns,   death threats, and blacklisting, Kevin has  earned Nobel Peace Prize nominations for his   relentless pursuit of justice. Through his radio  program, Here We Stand, in the Republic of Canada,   a movement for self-governance under common law,  Kevin has inspired thousands to reject centralized   power. His tireless advocacy from indigenous  communities to international tribunals amplifies   the marginalized and challenges the powerful. Now  in books he's written like Truthteller Shield,   a manual for whistleblowers and Hellraisers,  the theory and practice of letting your truth   and the truth prevail, which is a powerful manual  for empowering whistleblowers and truth tellers,   and another book, Governing Ourselves, a handbook  on personal, political, and spiritual sovereignty,   which we will be discussing and referring to  today. Kevin distills his decades of struggle   into a powerful guide for liberation. Co-authored  with indigenous elders, legal scholars, and global   activists, the book is both a manifesto  and a practical blueprint. It argues that   true freedom begins with reclaiming personal  agency, rejecting corporate and state control,   and embracing spiritual awakening. Drawing on the  Republic of Canada's experiments with common law   courts and citizens assemblies, this book offers  tools for building self-governing communities   rooted in equality and mutual accountability. It  is a call to action, urging readers to embody the   principle that we are beholden to none, save one  another, and the laws we establish. Kevin's life   is a testament to the power of one individual  to ignite change. From a small church in Port Al   Bernie to a global stage, he has exposed truths  that shook empires and inspired a movement for   sovereignty. As Kevin continues to lead by  example, his story reminds us that courage,   truth, and solidarity can dismantle even the  most entrenched systems of oppression. In a world   hungry for freedom, Kevin stands as a beacon,  showing us how to govern ourselves and build a   future worthy of our highest aspirations. Before  wrapping up the introduction of today's guest,   I'd like to give just a couple quick reminders and  updates. If you're interested in being a guest on   the show, if you wanted to share any information  privately with me, or if you are interested in   submitting a written testimony to be featured on  my Substack, you can reach out to me via email   at imagine a better world2020@gmail.com  or standby survivors at protonmail.com.   Additionally, I've teamed up with a couple  of my favorite brands to offer you exclusive   discount codes on products I love, such as Refe  Technology Frequency Machines and CZTL's Premium   Methylane Blue. You can find all the relevant  links and codes along with other resources   down below in the show notes. Your support  across all platforms is greatly appreciated,   especially as I've had to shift to alternative  streaming platforms such as Rumble and X following   the extreme censorship that caused my last YouTube  channel to be terminated. I've just started a new   YouTube channel and you can subscribe to me there  at the handle Imagination Podcast official that   I am now streaming new episode premieres from  weekly. This transition to multiple platforms   is crucial to continue sharing vital information  with the public and disclosure communities. So,   thank you all on the other side of the screen  for helping to make the imagination the safest   space on the internet for survivor whistleblower  advocate and educator disclosures. Your support   means the absolute world to me and to every guest  on the show. So you guys, without further ado,   please help me in welcoming back today's guest of  honor. Voice for the voiceless, relentless victim   and survivor advocate, passionate purveyor of  truth, content creator, author and writer, human   rights activist, absolute warrior, and a man whose  actions speak louder than any words. The one,   the only Kevin Annit. Kevin, thank you so much for  being here with us again today. It's always such   an honor to have you on. Oh, it's always a joy to  be back. Thank you, Emma. You're so welcome. I'm   excited for for today's topic and you know, we've  had some really great podcast episodes. The thing   I was telling you before we started recording  that I really love about working with you is   you're so knowledgeable about so much. So, there's  so much that we can talk about whether it's as a   big picture or sort of a focused detail. And so,  today I'm really excited for this conversation.   And I think it's really going to help people  feel empowered to take their sovereignty into   their own hands and to sort of have a direction on  how to do that. So I thought maybe we could start   um you're actually working with some groups right  now helping produce and manifest in real life   this exact topic that we're talking about today  personal and um sovereignty throughout a nation   or throughout a community. And so I thought I  would give you an opportunity to share a little   bit about that because it's really revolutionary  what you're doing. Well, in what other more and   more people are doing um in two places in America  and England this last month there's been a real   coalescing of people who some of whom we inspired  but other people have just come forward. It's kind   of like this hundth monkey phenomenon. People have  just come from everywhere all of a sudden and I   mean that is reflected in the fact that we sold  over 1,200 of my books in the last two months.   normally in the same period of time would sell  maybe 50 or 100. So it's going through the roof   now this interest and yeah you you mentioned this  book and they both both in America and England   these new groups are relying heavily on this. I'll  tell you about them. First of all, uh in England   for a number of years, people have been trying to  they've shown kind of a passive interest in what   we're doing in Canada because we're facing the  same uh institution of the crown, right? And this   last month, a organizing committee has formed  to establish a republic, sovereign republic in   England called the Republic of Albon. Albio N.  And uh that's a traditional Gaelic word. It kind   of embraces a lot of the culture there and um it  also reflects the fact that historically there   was a republic in England. It's in under Cromwell  and the Puritans when they cut off the c the head   of the king Charles um in 1649 for 11 years they  had a republic. Parliament abolished the monarchy   and the house of lords and said it was a crime of  treason to reestablish the British monarchy. Well,   um, Charles II comes along, does a military coup,  overthrows the republic, and reestablishes the   monarchy, but it was never a dour or lawful power.  It was kind of a de facto coup, but it it's never   had, in other words, the British crown has not  had lawful authority since 1649. It's a power,   but not a lawful one. And that really helped us  when we set up the Republican Kennetic as we said,   look, it's always been a fiction, literally  the authority of the crown. Well, the folks   in England, they've now reached a critical mass  and they now have organizing committees in four   different areas in Ireland because there is  kind of a cultural and historical affinity   in the north of Ireland, um Scotland, Wales, and  England. Okay? And they they have a flag uh which   they're just uh I'll send it to you later. You can  post it. We uh they're just in the process of kind   of finalizing it, but it'll have the symbols  of those four cultures on it. and um uh they   have agreed to very much follow the setting kind  of the outline we did in Canada which is they've   uh decided on a constitution they're going to go  public and say look this is not just replacing a   figurehead uh knocking out a king and putting  in a president right this is an transformation   from the grassroots so they're they'll be setting  up as we did uh local republic assemblies courts   um their own sheriffs to enforce it, making  the appeal to people to switch allegiance,   nullify their oath of allegiance to Charles  and the crown and take it to constitution. So   reviving the republic, that's in their tradition.  As a matter of fact, it was interesting because   after the republic got overthrown, a lot of those  folks came to came to America to New England.   Um it was interesting early on people know the  story of the Mayflower landing at Plymouth Rock   in 1620. 50 years following that uh there were um  people who used to be in the new model army who   fought with Cromwell who had come over refugees  from England and these folks wrote out the early   statements in Connecticut and Plymouth of what  their republic should look like. that is they   formed the first covenant the first real identity  the new identity people had that we are Americans   because we are governing ourselves we're not  beholden to any ruler any monarch you know   um and so there was that continuity you know from  England to America and the same thing's happening   now because part two of this is in America there  is uh now we're in touch with people in uh 14   different states who are interested in this and  what they're doing is they want to issue a new   Declaration of Independence against the existing  system and they've they've united Democrats and   Republicans because they've lost the old labels.  These are Americans who are saying one of the the   people had at one of these meetings I took part  in on a Zoom call. They had a big flag on the   wall that said neither Republican nor Democrat but  American going back to the roots of who we all are   and making that that unity again. And people are  so hungering for that, right? and um you know this   divisive conflict that's been going on. people now  in America are saying we need a new declaration to   remind us of what to recover our soul to remind  us at the heart of America is the fact that not   only are all people created equal but they remain  equal and they've got to establish their own way   to govern themselves in in the law in politics in  everything so that all the citizens are involved   that you know for example there should be no laws  passed in which we haven't had a say the best laws   come out of our own communities where people get  together and say what do we want how do we want   our communities to be and work that away from the  grassroots. So it's really exciting. They want to   issue this. They haven't set a date but they're  they're holding like what happened in 1770s. U   they're holding constitutional conventions all  over and they're making an appeal to people to   come out from these labels of Republican Democrat.  Forget about the politicians no matter who they   are. This is not an attack on anyone. It's an  a reminder of America is a lot more than its   politicians or its government. It's in the heart  and soul of the people and we're trying to recover   that soul. So it was beautiful. I was had tears  in my eyes after talking to these folks because   it's like you know finally it's happening where  it should because I still believe that America   and what it embodies is the hope of the world in  the sense that you know the common law republic   was a fact here. It wasn't just an nice nice idea.  It's it's it keeps rising up through slavery and   through all of these wrong turns that the country  took. There's this this kind of gyroscope that   keeps bringing us back on course all the time,  right? It and and and that's a sign that the whole   world needs in this age of the corportocracy.  It's either a republic or this corporate monolith   that's at the heart of all of these problems and  crimes we've been talking about. So, those are two   really exciting developments. And um of course,  they want me to come over to England in the fall   and I'll be down in the States as well helping  with all this. But, oh my gosh, it's really great.   me. I love that people are finding your work and  starting to learn about these things. You know,   I can't believe that this stuff isn't common  knowledge to people living in society. You know,   people are just now finding out about this decades  into their life and saying, "Oh, wait. I don't   have to accept what's always been there. I can  use my voice and get a group of people together   and make a change." And I really love that you're  being brought in on behalf of um these different   movements especially that have to do with politics  because unfortunately you know politics I think   was rooted in maybe doing something good and  creating law and order. However, throughout time   and and especially now, the only purpose it really  serves is to get people to hate one another. And   it creates these little pockets of division and  really compartmentalizes people from their own   communities, you know, and then they get so caught  up in idolizing these people that don't know them,   that don't give a crap about them, you know, and  and ultimately we're destroying ourselves from   the inside out because these policies have been  so inverted to work against us, you know. So,   I really love that you're seeing people sick of  that and saying, "What are we doing?" You know,   let's all unite together in our own communities  and and as a nation and throw out these different   divisive tactics. We're better together. And  that really says a lot about your work and the   way that you've presented it that way. Right. And  that's, you know, the power of this book and and   the folks in America and England both said the  same thing about this even though they hadn't   been in communication. They're all just observing  this that the power of this it combines all three   personal political spiritual and I go into detail  of what that looks like and not just me there was   this was actually co-written with five other  people people in our republic movement in in   also from other countries uh you know like  Tom House he's a traditional Ojiway elder   who I've known for many years who is sits on  the national council of the republic in Canada   um and so when you said politics the you know  in here We explain that the word comes from the   Greek word polus p o l i s and all that meant in  in the Greek language was the city because they   were referring to Athens which was the first place  in the world that people practice participatory   democracy not representative where you sign your  authority away to one guy and he does whatever   he wants and you only have a say you know at the  next election. Somebody did a funny cartoon. It   shows a guy in a holding up a piece of paper paper  and there's 10 X's on it and he says here's your   lifetime ration of democracy, right? 10 crosses  every time you vote. And Jeanjac Rouso in the   social contract in the 1700s he wrote that he said  in the English system of representative democracy   you only have a moment of freedom when you choose  somebody but then you lose freedom again because   they are representing you right that's not  the Athenian model. 500 years before Christ,   they had a model in ancient Athens which  was better than what we brought now. And   first of all, every citizen was expected to  participate. So they had big assemblies and   um now of course citizen meant the non-slaves  and women of course weren't included.
